newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Pilots warn of strike at Portugal's TAP.
newsitem.headline: Pilots warn of strike at Portugal's TAP.

text.p: Portugal's main pilots' union has told state carrier TAP-Air Portugal that it was planning an indefinite strike from later this month to protest against the airline's inefficient organisation of pilots' working hours.

A TAP spokeswoman, who asked not to be identified, said the airline had received written notice on July 15 of the planned strike from midnight local time (2300 GMT) on July 27 if it did not comply with strict conditions on pilots' working hours.

A copy of the strike warning from the Civil Aviation Pilots' Union (SPAC), made available to Reuters, said the strike was being planned as a protest against the "disorganisation of pilot stopovers". SPAC represents all of TAP's 430 pilots.
One SPAC official, Angelo Felgueiras, told TSF radio that the stoppage was to protest against the poor organisation of pilots' working hours and accused the airline of bad management.
Diario de Noticias newspaper reported on Wednesday that the strike could lead to the cancellation of 15 percent of TAP's flights and cost the airline 3.3 billion escudos ($18 million) in August.
In April TAP pilots staged a two-day stoppage over working hours, which grounded international flights and left around 14,000 passengers stranded.
SPAC represents a total of 1,100 civil aviation pilots in Portugal, including pilots from other airlines.
-- David Brough, Lisbon newsroom +351-1-3538254 ($ = 183.7 Portugese Escudos)
